content: a fountain in the jungle spewing liquid gold makes little to no sense I realize
that but I also realized something far more important it doesn't freakin matter
because it's cool hey guys welcome back to Blackmagic
craft jungle-themed terrain is something that's received little to no attention
on this channel I really don't have much of it in my collection I made these
scattered plants years ago but that's really about it so I'm super excited to
share this build with you guys today I built this one tier of salt I themed
jungle trying temple snake God thing it was inspired by a miniature from this
week's sponsor project dark water realistically this is not something
that's gonna get a lot of in-game use from me for tabletop RPGs it's the kind
of thing you can only bust out once or twice and it could make for a really
cool encounter situation I imagine adventurers stumbling upon this thing
and this weird liquid gold that they could maybe use to dip their weapons in
to give them some kind of magical abilities or whatnot think silvering but
more more good project dark water sent me a bunch of prototype minis to work
with from their Kickstarter project and while the hero models were all very nice
it was the larger monster minis that really appealed to me and got me excited
to integrate them into a larger piece of those it was this really bizarre snake
creature thing that stood out I just love the look of it to me it screamed
awesome statue or altar because it had flowing liquid integrated into the
sculpt it only made sense that it would be made into some sort of fountain or
pool I grabbed the first circular thing I could find that was about the right
size that I wanted so I could trace out a base on to medium weight chipboard
since I was envisioning this being an ancient structure built by snake people
and crumbling in the jungle I didn't want nice uniform bricks I wanted a
variety of different shapes and sizes to make a less technologically advanced
looking structure this was a perfect opportunity to show you that you can
still do these sort of builds with just a knife I grab some scrap XPS foam and
cut up a bunch of randomly sized bricks using my trusty Olfa blade with a
mountain of bricks ready I busted out my super high-end expensive and complicated
brick tumbler to give the foam piece of some texture and to smooth out all the
edges assembly is where things got a bit
difficult with these randomly shaped bricks it takes a lot more time and
effort to build walls this way because things end up at all sorts of different
heights making overlapping way more difficult than when you're using uniform
bricks but if you're willing to put in the effort you can get some really
cool-looking patterns once I got a few rows high I realized I
was getting a bit of a bow or bubble in my chipboard vase I thought it would be
a good idea to fill it with something solid before building the walls any
higher I needed something that I could pour in and that would set up quickly
for this I utilized quick set drywall joint compound this stuff hardens via
chemical reaction rather than evaporation so you can mix it really
thin and have it harden in like 20 to 30 minutes there's probably all sorts of
other plasters that would work just as well or even better but this quick set
compound is something that I just always have on hand for quick drywall repairs
after curing it had created two weird
ditches in the underside of the chipboard the piece sat pretty flat and
I probably could have gotten away with keeping it like this but since I wanted
it to have an overgrown jungle look a decorative base would actually be a
really good fit here even though I tend to avoid them when possible I cut out a
larger base in some 3/16 of an inch MDF and I beveled the edges with an orbital
sander if I were to do this again I just skipped the paper chipboard base I
started with and build right off of the MDF to begin with while I continue the
tedious process of laying bricks I want to take a minute to talk more about the
sponsor of this week's video project dark water has launched a Kickstarter
for a DND five East supplement titled veil of ruin they've created a unique
campaign setting and will be releasing a ton of cool items to help you run a game
within it the lost touch adventure book will be available in PDF and hardcover
and includes hero packages new classes subclasses beats and magic there's also
a full bestiary and tons of other goodies the Codex book is also available
in PDF and hardcopy and it's gonna give you more tools for a unique adventure
with all new playable races sub-races backgrounds magic items and more various
levels of pledges will include other neat physical goodies like acrylic
skinny minis fold-out maps GM screens bonus STL files posters booklets and
most exciting the miniature package this miniature
package consists of the six heroes as well as some villains including this big
bad snaky boy I'm working with today the project is a bit too big in scope for me
to give you a perfect overview in this short sponsor spot so I encourage you to
jump over to their Kickstarter which I'll link below there you can take some
time to browse over all of the goodies that they've created for this exciting
world personally I'm a big fan of adventure packages that give GM's a
variety of tools that they need to run a unique campaign
this project is the perfect example of how to do that properly
I used this build to test an idea that I
have been wanting to try for a while grout I wanted to see if using real grow
would be a good option for mortar between bricks when I build using
uniform bricks I actually like the small spaces to remain open so it helps shows
that brick pattern but with this sort of random size build the gaps are just too
big the idea here is to use regular unsanded grout tile to apply it in the
same way you would on tiles in your house this would hopefully give a really
nice look while adding a lot of extra strength the nice thing about using grow
versus something like joint compound is that it's designed to be wiped away from
the surface and remain in the cracks and to my very happy surprise it really
worked well it was fast and easy to apply and clean up I noticed that it
actually colored the bricks in a really nice way so if you were to first paint
the bricks and use a color of grout that suited your project you may actually be
able to use this as a final step in your process and while that grow fully cured
I needed to build up the area of the pool with some sort of substance I
remembered a previous project where I made toxic goo using sculpt a mold
during that project I had a stage where the liquid was painted gold and I
thought it looked really cool so this is where my plan to turn this into a
fountain of gold came from sculpt the mold is one of my favorite materials to
work with it dries fast it's easy to smooth and it's very strong and durable
once cured it's essentially like that quick set joint compound I used earlier
but with paper fibers in it to give it a lot more strength to make some bubble
effects I use these half circle gems that you've probably seen me use in a
few of my builds the hardest part about placing bubbles is that it's really
tricky to make them look natural rather than trying to think about where
they should be placed I just drop them on and place them wherever they fell
this would give them a truly random look that my pattern-seeking animal brain
refused to just do intentionally before the
sculptor mold was completely dried I removed the mini so that I could paint
the two pieces separately I have a lot of fun painting this project I really
leaned on my airbrush here I know this is a tool that can seem intimidating for
a lot of beginners but I gotta say it shouldn't be I'm by no means a great
painter a hell I'm barely a good painter I don't aim for paint jobs that will
impress good painters I am for paint jobs that will impress the average
person someone who's not into this hobby while remaining really easy to
accomplish I'm not gonna lie I'm a lazy painter and I'm okay with
that as a terrain builder especially for tabletop RPGs where things get used only
a couple times I actually think this is a good trait to have I look for methods
that have the best ratio of effort to result just like a simple grayscale dry
brush paint job creates a decent look with almost no skill or effort zenithal
highlight Prime with some spray cans followed by airbrushing on some inks
creates a surprisingly good look that requires absolutely no real skill it's
also a really fast process I was able to prime and paint this piece in under 30
minutes maybe about 20 and that's including drying time between coats
that's incredible as far as I'm concerned so if you've been thinking of
an airbrush as some sort of intimidating Pro tool you should honestly reconsider
with a fairly small investment in a cheap compressor and a decent airbrush
you can be banging out nice-looking paint jobs in unbelievably short times
with surprisingly little effort taking this leap in my hobby Eng has been one
of the most exciting and liberating steps I've taken over the past few years
now inspired by painted sculptures from Bali specifically I thought it would be
a nice touch to paint out the feathers and eyes on the snake I wasn't trying to
paint them to look like real feathers or eyes I wanted them to look like a metal
sculpture that had been painted with some bold colors I think this was a
small but important detail to give this project a little bit of that
character to decorate the base I use PVA glue someplace and and a bunch of unused
teabag fillings the trick to doing this is to spray it afterwards with
watered-down PVA Mod Podge or scenic cement
unfortunately the tip of my spray bottle for this had gone wonky and I couldn't
get it cleaned and cleared enough to spray properly so I ended up just
putting on a normal tip and pouring on the watered-down Mod Podge which created
a huge mess what really helps to sell the look of overgrown jungle however is
cool plants and I have a bunch of these plastic plants that I bought I think
from Michael's years ago if you cut them up and place them creatively it's pretty
easy to make believable looking ferns and jungle plants a glued snakey boy in
place and used a little bit of modeling paste to hide the seam on the liquid
gold I went for this option because I could immediately brush on some gold
paint to undercoat it before the final gold airbrushing I didn't have to wait
for it to dry first now this here really highlights again why fallen head over
heels in love with using an airbrush all those bits of tea and plastic plants
don't look quite right as is they both need to be filtered with some color
doing that with a brush would be really tricky but a bit of dark brown and green
inks sprayed all over blends it all together it's a great way to take these
fake looking plastic foliage pieces and make them actually look somewhat
believable that fake plastic look has honestly been what prevented me from
using these plants a lot more in the past so I'm really excited to have
discovered an easy way to overcome that I did a final coat of airbrushed gold
but I still wasn't quite happy with it somehow it just looked too solid and dry
and hard it didn't really look like liquid so I did something risky
I took some Vallejo water texture and mixed in some gold paint into it to pour
on to everything the hope here was that it will look more like liquid gold and
it looked really neat while it was wet but I had no idea how it would cure I
could already tell that the metallic pigments and the paint were too heavy
and would probably end up settling as the
water texture cured because it takes several hours for this stuff to harden
up and during this process I did come and check on it a few times to swirl it
around and try to preserve that neat swirly look but in the end most of the
water texture just became invisible and just ended up looking like a gloss
varnish in the areas where it was really thick it ended up looking like dirty
water overtop of gold now this was an ideal and it wasn't what I had planned
but still I'm pretty happy with it
I really had a lot of fun building this one well actually that's not true
building it was a bit of a pain but I had a ton of fun painting it and adding
all the finishing details I'm really loving doing bricks and stones in a more
far-out color scheme it's pretty cool to have green bricks instead of your
typical gray ones and while I'm still not the biggest fan of decorated bases
on terrain on projects like this I think it's far better looking to have one I'd
love to see this with a set of matching scatter terrain for some sort of
skirmish game I don't play anything I need it for
so hopefully you do and hopefully this inspires you to make something similar
so what do you guys think I mean I like it do you like it let me know what you
think of this build in the comments section below and if you like this video
don't forget to hit that like button now if you want to pick up any tools or
supplies for your own hobby needs maybe something like a starter airbrush set or
I don't know some sculpt amoled head over to black magic crafts dot CA there
I've curated a really helpful resource where I link and explain all the stuff I
use so if you don't know what to buy that that's what it's for use it check
it out and if you really like these videos that
I make every week if you get value out of them if they help you if they make
your life more enjoyable and better consider supporting the channel on
patreon it's through that support that I'm able to dedicate my time and effort
into making these videos I'd love to have you as the newest member of the
black magic crafts fellowship I gotta again say thank you to project dark
water for sponsoring this video I love having on themed hobby related
sponsors for my content and they really help me share my love of the Hobby with
you guys so good luck with your Kickstarter don't forget you guys to
check it out link will be in the video description below that's it for this
week guys I'll see you again next week and just look at this mess this what my
desk actually usually looks like when I'm in the middle of a build
you just start to go kind of out of control
